responses.author: greatpurplepenguins
responses.resp_content: I'm sure you've heard this before, but have you tried Polyethylene Glycol (Miralax)? It's gentle (but effective if taken daily) and considered safe for daily use. It helps me quite a bit. I have similar problems and a sensitive stomach as well. I'd start with two doses in one day (one in the morning and one in the evening) and then one every day until you have a good bm. Then I'd use it like every-other day, or experiment and see what works for you. It's quite safe, really.

post.author: eugenew
post.post_content:
I'm writing this post in regards to my mother. For several years she has suffered from an undiagnosed gastrointestinal condition that has been increase in severity. Her symptoms include extreme bloating (it looks like there's a balloon under her shirt at times), nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and over the past 3 months she has lost significant weight (20 - 30 lbs). Episodes exhibiting these symptoms occur usually after a meal, however more recently these episodes have begun to increase in frequency (happening regardless of what/when she eats), severity, and length.

Over the years, my mother has visited numerous doctors and has undergone a litany of medical tests/screenings, most recently being an exploratory endoscopy during an August 2016 hospital stay. Biopsies were performed and returned negative. The tests and screenings have all come back inconclusive or with negative results. Doctors have suggested my mother adopt a gluten free diet, which she has since 2014. Overall my mother's diet has consisted of gluten free waffles for breakfast, peaches, or blueberries on top, small coffee black, chicken broth, boiled chicken, and occasionally a rice noodle dish from the local Asian food place. However, lately she has been unable to eat much as these episodes of extreme bloating and discomfort have been occurring much more frequently.

Currently, she is on a medical leave from work. She has bad days and better days, but lately its been seeming like she is constantly in pain, unable to eat or get out of bed.

responses.author: rohvannyn

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_content: Looking for insight... I have been struggling with acid reflux/GERD since I was 18 years old. Over the years I tried every drug available with my doctors help and was never able to get anything to work. I was taking upwards of 5 Prilosec a day at one point trying to get relief. Finally, I came across Dexilant which she gave me samples of that seemed to cure my Reflux instantly. I have taken it now for probably the past five years or so, 60mg a day. This year however I had to switch insurance carriers and my new insurance refuses to cover this drug. I came off of it back in June and have been having serious problems ever since. My reflux is out of control and seems to be getting worse. Five to six prilosec a day won't even touch it. Nexium only made it worse. I met with my doctor who sent me for tests and referred me to a Gastroenterologist. I am a singer, it's my love and passion and this is destroying my ability to do that. post.author: lindsnav
post.post_content:
Hello! I am 24 years old and was told I have GERD by a doctor a little over a month ago after experiencing a week + of constant and extreme burning sensations in my stomach/chest, an awful taste in my mouth and morning breath, an increase in burping, a huge increase in saliva production (which I used to associate with the feeling of vomiting) and not being able to stand up straight without feeling worse. My doctor immediately came to the conclusion that I had GERD and prescribed a PPI - 20mg of omeprazole to take once daily, in the morning 30 mins before eating. I have been taking the pills religiously and have made a complete lifestyle change; cut out all food/liquids that I read can irritate my stomach, eating smaller meals more frequently and slowly, been careful to not lay down until at least 2 hours after eating, completely stopped drinking alcohol and all caffeine (except the occasional herbal green tea that is caffeinated). In other words, I feel I have made all the right steps and should be feeling much better... And I was until about 1 week ago... I started to get a tickle in my throat and a runny nose, which at first I just attributed to a regular old common cold. However this cold is different than any other I've experienced; a constant cough and mucus, wheezing in my chest before/during/and after coughing, constant extremely runny nose, the burning pain I experienced before my lifestyle changes & meds in my stomach when coughing, the weird taste in my mouth after coughing/sniffling mucus, occasional but extreme dizziness, and occasional but extreme shortness of breath while talking even at a very low decibel.

Sorry I know this is such a long post but I am desperate to see if anyone else has experienced anything like this. I originally thought it was an unrelated sickness but now I feel that my GERD and this freak cold may be linked somehow. I am very frustrated because I have completely committed to trying to fix the issue to no avail. I am a waitress and I am completely embarrassed having these issues while taking care of people & their food and cannot afford to take anymore time off work. I plan on heading back to the doctor as soon as I can make time, but since my insurance is pretty awful to non existent I was hoping someone may have some advice.

Thanks for taking the time to read this!

responses.author: lindsnav
responses.resp_content: I should also say that I am in good shape and not over weight, I do not smoke, I am a pescetarian and I have a very active job.

responses.author: WebMD Addie
responses.resp_content:
I am so sorry to hear that your symptoms have come back after putting so much time and energy into making the lifestyle changes that you described. I hope that someone who has personal experience with something similar is able to chime in soon. I think that making another appointment to see your doctor when you are able is absolutely the right thing to do. Continuing to work with a medical professional can help you narrow down if these cold symptoms and the recurrence of your GERD symptoms are in fact related.

Did you make any changes in your diet or elsewhere in your life in the time leading up to your symptoms beginning again? Have you noticed your symptoms getting worse after you eat a particular food or do a particular activity? It may help to keep a journal of your symptoms, what you're eating and drinking, when they seem to get worse, etc., so that when you see your doctor you are prepared to answer any questions.

This article ( http://wb.md/2cpUgKJ) does say that GERD is a common cause of unexplained coughing and lists some other symptoms that you may want to take a look at and compare to what you are experiencing.

I know you've read a lot of information on triggers and have changed your diet accordingly, but it may also be helpful to look through this slideshow of foods to eat and foods to avoid to see if there is anything you haven't considered yet: http://wb.md/2czdCSo

Finally, here is a link to our Heartburn/GERD center ( http://wb.md/2cyDBrR) There may be some more information there that could help answer some of your questions.

Please check in and let us know how you're doing!

responses.author: harragoo
responses.resp_content:
You've probably figured it out by now, but I came online today for a similar reason. I have GERD and usually the symptoms are mild.

Yesterday they suddenly got much worse, for no apparent reason, and today I woke up with a bad head cold. I wondered if a regular common cold could trigger GERD symptoms. Reading your post, it seems like perhaps it can.

However, I will say that I've had almost all the symptoms you're describing WITHOUT having an actual cold, just from a bad episode of GERD.

post.author: kuyaromeo1
post.post_content:

It's near the base of my throat. It does not impact my breathing and I can still eat and drink without issue. As a matter of fact, swallowing food or liquid makes it feel better for just a few moments.

As the night progressed, I had an extended case of the hiccups. But it did not help. I have now had this feeling of something stuck in my throat for three days. It's accompanied by constant burping (small burps).

I have tried warm and cold water - no success
I have tried Rolaids and Tums - didn't do anything to help
I have tried forcing myself to vomit - which brought up food I had recently eaten - but did not help the feeling go away.

It does not hurt but it can be annoying and uncomfortable.

I recently started taking Lamisil pill orally for Toe Nail Fungus. I know that can have strange side effect - but I have not read anything about this as possible side effect.

Any ideas if this sounds like GERD or heartburn? And what I can do to make this feeling go away?

responses.author: WebMD Addie
responses.resp_title: RE: Something Stuck in My Throat?
responses.resp_content:
Hi kuyaromeo1 I'm sorry that you've been going through this. I can only imagine how uncomfortable it must be to always feel as if you have something stuck in your throat. This slideshow ( http://wb.md/2cAr3NQ) is an overview of heartburn and GERD and has some information that I think you may find helpful to click through. It does say that for some people, symptoms of severe acid reflux can include difficulty swallowing or the feeling that food is stuck in the chest or throat.

It may be a good idea to see your doctor for an exam. You may be able to take some steps to manage your symptoms at home, but it's important to find out if what you are experiencing is in fact heartburn or GERD. Here are some steps your doctor may take to find out if you do have heartburn or GERD: http://wb.md/2cfSlut

Please let us know how you're doing!

responses.author: harragoo
responses.resp_title: RE: Something Stuck in My Throat?
responses.resp_content:
That's how my GERD went from mild to severe - I fell down hard on my side, and afterwards I felt like I had swallowed a bug, like something stuck in my throat.

The book "Killing me softly from inside" has helped me manage my heartburn. You avoid certain foods that can make it flare up, and you never ever lie down for three hours after eating.

It has been almost 25 years since I had been experiencing IBS problems. I tried all possible diet controls but nothing worked. One fine day my doctor suggested to try Yoga and I joined an institute. There they analyzed my problems and assigned an instructed who taught me some relaxation techniques using Yoga therapy. I do that every day for about 30 mins (both morning and evening) in empty stomach. In addition I also reduce my food intake per sitting. Feeling a lot better now.
The incomplete finish feeling during bowel movements also improved with the above actions.

responses.author: Anonymous
responses.resp_content: Can you share some of the relaxation techniques they suggested for you? I had a friend suggest that I do the "superman" yoga pose when I am feeling particularly bloated or crummy. It's the one where you lay on your stomach, put your legs straight behind you and arms straight in front and then lift them all up off the floor, lower down and repeat. It really has worked wonders. Although as a warning, you will probably pass gas :) Not sure why it works but just glad it does. Always looking for other things that might work too. Thanks!

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_title: Severe Bloating, stomach pain, and weight gain
post.post_content: Hi. I started with these symptoms about 2 years ago, and I have found no answers to my questions. So, I am here asking for help & support. I suffer with painful bloating from my first bite of my first meal until bedtime. By the end of the day, my stomach is so distended that I look pregnant. I also have been gaining a few pounds a week despite not eating much. My doctor has tried Augmentin for bacteria in my stomach. That failed, so I am on Xifaxan for bacteria in my stomach. This has all been trial and error by my md to help figure out what will work. I had a gastric emptying test done, and the results showed that my food leaves my stomach and travels through properly. Why am I feeling so bloated? I am also gaining weight and I barely eat anything all day because I am so bloated. I am staying away from breads, fatty food, and processed foods. But still no relief. I am on the fence for getting a colonoscopy because I just don't think it will show anything. I am so frustrating and gaining weight as we speak. I lived with the bloating & pain, but I cannot live with the weight gain. Any ideas anyone?

responses.author: songbird1178
responses.resp_title: RE: Severe Bloating, stomach pain, and weight gain
responses.resp_content:
I think it's great that you've continued to work with your doctor -- it took me a long time to get to the point of reaching out for help. I think that for many of us here it has been a trial and error process that you describe until you find that one thing that answers your questions.

Have you tried a more strict elimination diet? I also have severe, painful bloating when I eat specific foods (although I have not experienced the weight gain that you are). A friend suggested I start by getting rid of all dairy in my diet, which definitely helped but didn't stop all my bloating. Then I moved on to getting rid of breads and other gluten foods. I also can't eat certain foods like apples, onions (unless they are well cooked), bananas (unless they are blended in smoothies -- weird I know), and others. It took me a long time to identify the foods that trigger my bloating, and I'm still finding new ones. When I do accidentally eat something I shouldn't, my stomach gets painfully hard and I can't do anything but lay on a hard surface and wait for it to go away. Sometimes pulling my knees to my chest and rocking or laying on my stomach and doing the "superman" workout move relieves some of the discomfort. I drink something called Calm every night before bed to try and get my BMs regular.

I've seen many doctors and had a couple of colonoscopies -- gone down the route of testing for Crohn's, celiac, etc. My doctors still haven't found an official dianosis -- just an intolerance to a number of foods, maybe IBS? But my experience definitely doesn't mean that a colonoscopy won't find answers for you. I would make sure to talk through the pros and cons of getting one with your doctor.

For now I'm doing ok managing my symptoms with food while I continue to search for answers. I hope that you find the answers you're looking for soon!
1

responses.author: WebMD Addie
responses.resp_title: RE: Blood and Mucus in Stool
responses.resp_content:
Finding blood in your stool can be scary, but it's important that you don't panic. Because there are so many possible causes of blood in your stool, the best thing that you can do is to see your doctor -- especially if this has become an ongoing issue.

Here is some information on possible causes of blood in stool (an anal fissure is one), how your doctor may diagnose what is causing your symptoms, and treatment options that may be available to you: http://wb.md/2cPwxsv

Here is some information specific to anal fissures that might help you further compare the symptoms listed to what you are experiencing: http://wb.md/2cPwqNe

As the first article says, it's important to have a doctor evaluate any ongoing bleeding in the stool. Your doctor will hopefully be able to identify if your pain and bleeding are in fact being caused by an anal fissure, or if it is something else, after listening to your symptoms and conducting a physical exam.

Please let us know how you are doing!

responses.author: zenmamasan
responses.resp_title: RE: Blood and Mucus in Stool
responses.resp_content: Yeah that can be scary, but the best thing to do is visit your doctor, it is recommended anytime you have a change in bowel habits and ahve blood in stool, you should see a doctor for a fecal occult {I think that is what it is called} They can tell by the type of blood whether coming from intestines, or closer to the surface. So no worries yet, just get that done. Knowledge is power.

Recently with my throat so sore, red and feeling swollen on the inside, my Doctor diagnosed me with LPR (Laryngopharyngeal Reflux Disease). My Dr. told me to raise the head of my bed (on wooden blocks-about 16 inches off the ground)-done! I've been doing some 'research' on myself-trying to discover what meds, if any, may be causing this severity of symptoms. I have missed doses of 'these 6 or 7 meds' and only taken 'these two meds' (this is just for example of course!) in order to find any one or two med that may be the ultimate culprit for this severity. It appears to be Lamictal and Trazodone (that I must take at bedtime every day for my Bi-polar disorder) that is causing the most serious symptoms of my acid reflux/LPR. I am wondering if these two meds alone could be causing me all this throat/voice box/larnyx pain and burning as well the regular symptoms of Gerd (nausea, heartburn, stomach pain etc.). I am actually in a predictament if these two meds are the cause as these two meds in combination work so well for my Bi-polar and I would not/would refuse to rock that boat! What to do? post.author: WebMD Addie
post.post_content:
New research suggests that people with severe chronic constipation may get relief from a more modern type of acupuncture -- something called electroacupuncture. It uses thin needles inserted beneath the skin that are attached to a device that sends electric pulses into the body.

You can read more about what researchers found, why they think it may have been successful, and the possible drawbacks here: http://wb.md/2c71e6y

Do you have severe constipation? Would you consider trying this?

post.author: aslbotf
post.post_content: Interesting: Gut bacteria affect your metabolism? http://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/what-your-gut-bacteria-say-your-health

post.author: autumnbreezes
post.post_content: having a really hard time with ibs almost no quality of life are there any new advances in medicine to control the outbreaks.

responses.author: WebMD Morgan
responses.resp_content:
Hi there,

I'm so sorry to hear that you are going through this. IBS doesn't just have a physical toll, but it also brings with an emotional toll to those it affects.

It says here ( http://wb.md/2bwEfGD) , that it's important to manage your symptoms by watching what you eat, getting plenty of rest, quitting smoking if you do, taking medicines which help to control IBS, and reducing stress (this is a big one for a lot of IBS sufferers).

Avoiding greasy foods and drinking plenty of water can help! Click here to read more about treating IBS ( http://wb.md/2buDvmI) . As someone with IBS, you should also talk to a doctor about which prescription medications are available to you to help ease your symptoms.

Have you expressed your concerns and symptoms to your doctor? If not, I highly suggest that you do. You don't deserve to suffer. There is hope and there ways to keep it under control.

Keep us updated. We are here for you ((hugs)).

responses.author: autumnbreezes
responses.resp_title: Thank you for answering. My doctor really doesn't say much I have had 3 colonoscopies with no problems so he says to go gluten free,gmo free andcarb free which is hard when everything and anything I eat has side effects like gas, bloating, and diarreha its really hard to be in public places with these symptoms let alone with friends and family

post.author: judieb
post.post_content: I was first diagnosed, by elimination, with IBS-C when I was in my 30s. From that time on I suffered occasional flares but usually in times of heay stress. About 18 months ago I began to have the flares more often and more severe. I eventually went to a GI doctor who, after a colonoscopy with biopsies came back clear, treated me with Amitiza 8mg, 1 twice a day, Bentyl 20 mg, 1 three times a day, and Ativan, 5 mg, 1 twice a day. This combination worked well for a period of time but then I began to suffer from bouts of diarrhea. It got to where I was moving back and forth between the two extremes most of the time. I asked my regular physician to take over the maintenance of my treatment. He asked me a lot of questions about how I felt and what was a regular routine was like for me. After his examination of my situation he took me off the Bentyl because he thought that it seemed to have made my digestive system too sluggish. He also did a blood panel test and discovered that my thyroid was severly underactive and my Vitamin D was very low. He put me on Synthroid 100 mcg, 1 a day, and Vitamin D3 5000 units, 2 a day. After a couple of weeks I began to see a difference in the way I felt overall. That relieved some of the stress I had been feeling which helped with the IBS. I have been experiencing some pain in my lower back with tingling especially in my right leg. I don't know if it is at all related to the other problems I have. I would appreciate any tips for handling IBS that anyone has discovered. I know pretty much what not to eat but I haven't found any type of IBS diet advising as to what to eat. Any ideas on that would be appreciated also. Thank you....

responses.author: WebMD Morgan
responses.resp_content:
Hi there!

First off, I'm so sorry to hear of your diagnosis. However, I am happy to see that you are being proactive and keeping your doctor in the loop! While IBS-C can be a frustrating and painful disease, there are ways to manage it! Never forget, you are NOT alone and we are here for you ((hugs)).

Here are links to information on WebMD that you might find helpful:

1) Treatment for IBS with constipation -- http://wb.md/2bMbPYn
2) A Diet for IBS-C -- http://wb.md/2c9evAj
3) Managing your symptoms -- http://wb.md/2bMmYdf

Keep us posted!

post.author: bethrandy
post.post_content: Can anybody help me? I'm new at this. I've been having a number of attacks of IBS along with panic and anxiety attacks, and it's become very difficult to function well. Any idea or suggestions?

responses.author: judieb
responses.resp_content:
I also suffer from IBS that is triggered by stress. My doctor prescribed Ativan which is an anxiety medication that is often used for IBS. It does help. The only thing I didn't like was that you have to take it daily, not just when you are stressed.
1

responses.author: WebMD Morgan
responses.resp_content:
Hi there and thanks for posting,

I 'm so sorry to hear that you're having such a hard time. According to this link ( http://wb.md/2bwGZip) , it's not entirely clear how stress, anxiety, and IBS are connected or which one comes first, but studies show that they can happen together. It's important to know that you're not alone and that there are ways to manage your anxiety and your IBS.

At this link ( http://wb.md/2c97HCJ) , it says that anti-anxiety medications, which are used to treat panic disorders and anxiety, can also help to ease the symptoms of IBS, which are sometimes caused by anxiety. I highly suggest reading more of the article. It gives a lot of great information about treatment options.

Here is a link ( http://wb.md/2bMil2M) to more information about the anxiety and IBS connection. It also says that stress management can be a great tool in managing your IBS symptoms. Have you ever spoken to a mental health professional? If not, then I highly suggest that you do. He/she can give you the tools to manage your anxiety, and by doing so, you might be be able to also manage your IBS.

Please be sure to come back and update us. We are here for you and we care about you ((hugs)).

post.author: loriemay
post.post_content: Trying to learn how to cope with it. What to eat? Sometimes my stomach hurts some. Any answers will be helpful. I'm wondering if my fibromyalgia is connected to it.

responses.author: Anonymous
responses.resp_content: There are many diets posted on the internet for the myriad of digestive health disorders. Some of the information conflicts so it's hard to know what is best for you. You should talk to your primary care or gastroenterologist to get their recommendations. I suffer from IBS and never know what foods are going to cause flare ups. I don't know about you but I isolate myself because of the possibility of having an incident. I hope you learn to cope with your illness and have a full life.

responses.author: WebMD Addie
responses.resp_content:
Hi loriemay Welcome to the message board! The previous poster is absolutely right, talking to your primary doc or gastroenterologist about which diet or treatment options may be right for you is the best first step that you can take.

While there is no magic diet that will work for everyone with UC, this slideshow ( http://wb.md/2bGg74Y) has some diet tips for UC as well as diet mistakes to avoid that may be helpful for you to look through and try out.

And for those times when you are having a flare, the suggestions in this slideshow may help to ease your symptoms: http://wb.md/2bVMgBr

Please let us know if you find any of these tips to be particularly helpful, or if you learn something interesting from your doctor!

post.author: WebMD Addie
post.post_title: Welcome to the Digestive Health Message Board
post.post_content:
We are so excited to finally be able to share our new boards with you!

Just a few housekeeping things to go over before you get started:

- Bookmark this page so you can easily find us any time

- Make sure you check back frequently as conversations are always being added and expanded

- Head on over to your Message Board profile (just click on your account avatar in the top right corner of the page) to update your personal story and add your photo

- Don’t see what you’re looking for? Look through the tags at the top of the page to customize your view to only see posts that interest you

- When creating a post, choose a tag to add that most clicks with you. (Using tags is encouraged but not required.)

- Like what you see? Or need help? Send us an email at CommunityManagement@webmd.net
